title: perseid-meteor-shower-2020-peak-week-best-time-spot
story: If skies are clear, the display of celestial fireworks should be visible across the UK from about midnight tonightuntil .am UK time on Thursday, August  - according to astronomers at Royal Observatory Greenwich.What are the Perseids The astronomical event is associated with the dusty debris left by Comet Swt-Tuttle, which orbits the sun once every  years.The meteoroids from the comet, mostly no bigger than a grain of sand, burn up as they hit the Earthrsquos atmosphere at  miles per second to produce a shooting stream of light in the sky.Peak temperatures can reach anywhere from ,C to ,C as they speed across the sky.The meteors are called Perseids because they seem to dart out of the constellation Perseus.The meteor shower began on July  and will continue to be visible until August .What have astronomers said Anna Ross, an astronomer at the Royal Observatory Greenwich, said the best time to spot the meteors is between midnight and .am on Thursday, when up to  meteors or ldquoshooting stars will be visible per hour, which is more than one every second.She told the PA news agency: ldquoThis makes the Perseids one of the most impressive meteor showers of the year.ldquoDuring the peak night of the shower, you will be able to find it in the north-east of the sky, getting higher throughout the night.ldquoYou donrsquot have to be able to see Perseus to spot meteors, however, as they will be moving away from the radiant across the whole sky in every direction.To make the most of the meteors, Ms Ross said observers should avoid well-lit and built-up areas and try to find an unobstructed view to the east.She added: ldquoFind a dark area and allow around  minutes for your eyes adapt to the dark.ldquoAs meteors move quite fast across the sky itrsquos best to look up without using telescopes or binoculars so you can see as much of the sky as possible.How regular will the meteors be The Perseids are one of the more active meteor showers on stargazersrsquo calendars, producing an average of between  and  shooting stars an hour at their peak.The shower in rsquos was especially active, delivering up to  meteors an hour at its height.While the shooting stars this year wonrsquot be quite as regular, stargazers can still expect to see around  of them an hour.Do I need special equipment to see the Perseids Meteor showers are typically visible with the naked eye, so no special equipment is needed, but those in rural areas with minimal light pollution will have a clearer view.Heading out to a dark spot is the best plan of action, but stargazers should allow around  minutes for their eyes to become accustomed to the dark.Patience is also a virtue, with shooting stars tending to appear in clusters, followed by a lull.The meteors will appear to come from the direction of the Perseus constellation in the north eastern part of the sky, although they should be visible from any point.A cloudy night could still scupper your chances of spotting any meteors, however, so keep your eye on weather forecasts.

title: new-head-education-named
story: Ms Brown is currently the chief operating officer for education with the local authority and will take the place of Fiona Robertson, who moved to a new post with Midlothian Council at the start of the year.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet spokesperson for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoLesley has a strong track record and will play a vital leadership role. title: east-lothian-council-musselburgh-racecourse-redundancies
story: In a move described by union officials as a ldquoworrying indication for the future, talks with a number of staff are being held.It is understood that three of the five ground staff who look after the course are being axed, leaving just two and the head groundsman.Racecourse manager Bill Farnsworth confirmed that redundancy talks were being held and pointed to the devastating impact of Covid- on the industry and Musselburghrsquos operations.However, GMB Scotland, which oversaw negotiations with East Lothian Council and Chester when the local authority brought them in to operate the racecourse, said it believed more options should have been considered.And it questioned how the award-winning course could keep up standardsthe workers involved were reduced so drastically.Benny Rankin, GMB Scotland organiser, said: ldquoWe are doing all we can to assist our members affected by these redundancies but there is no denying itrsquos a worrying indication for the future of this historic racecourse.ldquoWe believe that Chester havenrsquot explored all possible options to protect the employment of the existing workforce, including the use of the Government furlough scheme until its deadline, and this looks like the easy option rather than the right thing to do for the long-term.ldquoWe struggle to see how Musselburghrsquos five-star status can be sustainedsome of the workers who help make it what it is are losing their livelihoods, and it poses questions of the Chester management over their vision for the future of this course.Musselburgh Racecourse was run jointly by East Lothian Council and Lothians Racing Syndicate for more than a decade under the Musselburgh Joint Racing Committee.However, issues within the committee led to the British Horseracing Authority demanding an independent inquiry into its governance, which revealed a toxic relationship had developed between the two parties.The council set up Musselburgh Racing Associated Committeendash a new governance body ndash to oversee it as it sought a third-party operator to take over the management of the course.Staff at the racecourse at that point became council employees.When Chester took over on June , they transferred to the company.Mr Farnsworth said that the course finances had been hit by lockdown and, even when racing resumed behind closed doors, it was with no spectators or hospitality.He said: ldquoIt would be inappropriate to comment on the details but, like every racecourse in the country, we are having to review operational costs across the business in light of the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoThe reality is that since we resumed racing behind closed doors on June , we are a racecourse which is now racing again but without spectators, without hospitality revenues and with reduced sponsorship and media rights income.ldquoThe racecourse is unable to carry on as normal.ldquoLike every other business, be it in the sports, leisure, tourism, retail, professional services or industrial sectors, we are having to review everything we do in order to have a sustainable business, so that we can recover from the coronavirus pandemic.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, described the redundancies as ldquodeeply concerning.He said: ldquoThe change of ownership was meant to secure the course and the jobs, not threaten them.ldquoThese are dficult times but staff have maintained a marvellous facility before and during the crisis.ldquoThey are entitled to be treated better.ldquoIrsquoll be seeking assurances from the new management.

title: patrols-carried-human-waste-left-campers
story: Problems surrounding irresponsible campers were highlighted last month after reports of illegal fires being started and people leaving behind ldquotoilet paper and human waste.The disgusting image at Tyninghame Beach was highlighted by the countyrsquos countryside rangers.On Friday evening, with temperatures soaring across the country, they were joined by police officers in patrolling the beach.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed future patrols would also be carried out when the site was expected to be busy.She said: ldquoWe work closely with Police Scotland and other partners to manage responsible access to our coastal sites which includes matters such as parking capacity, wild camping and anti-social behaviour.ldquoOver the past months our countryside rangers have been carrying out patrols in and around our coastal sites engaging in particular with groups of campers.ldquoOn Friday, they were joined by colleagues from Police Scotland.ldquoThe purpose of these patrols is to provide information on responsible wild camping and behaviour in our countryside sites, and to discourage illegal camping and anti-social behaviour especially when it involves groups.ldquoWe intend to conduct these joint patrols over the busier weekends.Last month, countryside rangers revealed there had been an ldquounprecedented number of visitors along the East Lothian coast.The number was so large that some coastal car parks, including those at Tyninghame, Gullane and Yellowcraig, had to be closed.On one Saturday last month,  tents were found at Tyninghame, which equated to about  people camping in an area with no toilet facilities.Across East Lothian, more than  tents were found along the coastline.

title: delight-east-lothian-pupils-exam-results-u-turn
story: Exams were cancelled this year for students because of the coronavirus pandemic and teachers were asked to submit expected grades for each senior pupil based on prelim results and course work.However, the Scottish Qualications Authorityreviewed the submissions and using a lsquostatistical modelrsquo, which took into account the historic exam performances of schools, downgraded thousands of submitted grades, causing a national outrage.In East Lothian, , pupils received some grades which had been marked down.Only  of the , young people who were due to sit SQA exams had any of their final grades increased.The results dropped through letterboxes last Tuesday and sparked a furious backlash from students who received lower grades than expected.Erin Campbell, , Member of the Scottish Youth Parliamentfor Musselburgh, said many friends had been left worried and scared after the initial results came out, warning that the fiasco had been ldquobad for their mental health.Erin, who was a sixth-year student at Musselburgh Grammar School, said: ldquoOn a personal level, I was lucky to receive the results that I needed in order to move on to university however, I am aware of a lot of young people, including close friends, who were left scared and worried after not receiving a conditional offer to uni that was reliant on these results.ldquoThis badly impacted their mental health, particularly during the period of uncertainty before [Education Secretary] John Swinneyrsquos announcement [on Tuesday].Student protests were held in Glasgow and Edinburgh and politicians piled on pressure for the Scottish Government to step in and overturn the results.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray, Labourrsquos education spokesperson, called on Mr Swinney to resign after he initially backed the modied results before bending under pressure and telling the Scottish Parliament on Tuesday the Scottish Government had got it wrong.Mr Swinney said it was ldquodeeply regrettable we got this wrong and ordered the SQA to amend awards which had been marked down back to the submitted grade provided by teachers and reissue them.Mr Gray said Mr Swinney had spent five days defending the results before changing his position on Tuesday, asking him: ldquoWhy did he defend the results of this moderation for five days  Why did he leave these young people twisting in the wind for a week, hopes and aspirations in shreds Speaking after the decision, Mr Gray said: ldquoGiven the scale of the exam results scandal, it was inevitable that many local students would have been affected. I have certainly had a number of young people and parents contacting me over the last week to express their concerns about their grades being adjusted down by the SQA and the impact it might have on their futures.ldquoThe Scottish Governmentrsquos u-turn will bring relief to these worried young people and their families as they will now see their estimated results reinstated.ldquoHowever, the fact remains they should not have had to experience this worry and uncertainty in the first place. The Education Secretary has let them down and should be held accountable for this fiasco.Schools in East Lothian were yesterdaycontacting pupils who had been affected to let them know they would receive new awards.Across the county, , grades were submitted to the SQA for pupils at the end of May across National , Higher and Advanced Higher level by their teachers.In total, , were acceptedwith  adjusted upand ,adjusted down.In terms of pupils who were due to sit the exams, the council said just over  per cent saw at least one grade marked down.Councillor Shamin Akhtar , cabinet spokesperson for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoIrsquom delighted that John Swinney has finally decided to do the right thing for pupils on the exam results fiasco.ldquoYoung people have faced a very tough and stressful time already and this is something they should never have had to go through.ldquoSchool staff worked extremely hard to submit grades for their pupils to the SQA and the adjustments undermined their professional judgement.ldquoThis u-turn is a victory for young people who have led the campaign against the unfair results and should be commended for standing up for their rights.And Councillor Craig Hoy , a member of East Lothianrsquos education committee, said: ldquoI am delighted that grades have been restored to hardworking pupils in East Lothian who faced huge uncertainty over the last week for no good reason.ldquoEveryone can see that John Swinney has presided over a litany of failures, any one of which could have been a resignation issue on its own.ldquoThe SNP defended their appalling grading system to the hilt, even after it became clear that pupils, parents and teachers had no confidence in the system.On Monday, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon issued an apology to students across the country who had been marked down by the SQA.She said: ldquoOur concern, which was to make sure the grades young people got were as valid as in any other year, perhaps led us to think too much about the overall system and not enough about the inidual pupil.ldquoThat has meant too many students feel they have lost out on grades they should have had, and that that has happened not as a result of anything they have done but a statistical model or algorithm.ldquoDespite our best intentions, I do acknowledge that we did not get this right and I am sorry.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council welcomed the u-turn, adding: ldquoThroughout this process our schools have sought to represent the academic achievements of our young people in a way that provided a fair and accurate reflection of attainment using the guidance and methodology provided by the SQA.ldquoThe announcement by the Education Secretary will be welcomed by young people who saw their results downgraded, and by our teachers and schools who used their professional judgement when providing grade estimates.East Lothian MP Kenny MacAskillpledged his support to headteachers in a letter at the end of last week after the original results came out.He said: ldquoI welcome the Scottish Governmentrsquos announcement.ldquoAs I said last week in a letter to East Lothianrsquos headteachers, I believe the people best placed to know about pupils are those overseeing and working alongside them during their academic journeys.ldquoThis decision is the right one, and I want to send my congratulations to all students in East Lothian for the work they have achieved both before and during this pandemic, as well as a huge thanks to the teachers and school support staff who have worked so hard over the last few months.

title: betrayal-claim-mcdonalds-musselburgh-recommended-approval
story: In a letter to the Courier, Fraser McAllister hit out at their ldquoillogical recommendation which,approved by councillors at an online meeting next week, would grant permission for a restaurant to be created in the car park of the Tesco store off Olivebank Road.He claimed that the drive-thru, which would operate  hours a day, seven days a week, would be ldquonext to the most congested roundabout in the county.The former SNP councillor for Musselburgh West said: ldquoTragically,  local objectors and , petitioners have less value than the share value of these gigantic corporations.He called on councillors on the planning committee, which will debate the proposal on Tuesday, to halt the ldquobetrayal.Mr McAllister also lodged a formal objection, citing a range of concerns including traffic congestion, pollution, litter, obesity, residential amenity and economic damage.He claimed: ldquoThe custom predicted for this -hour McDonaldrsquos drive-thru and the intensity of the declared deliveries needed to service it are on an industrial scale. The impact on Olivebank Road would be truly calamitous.The plan will go before a lsquovirtualrsquo meeting of the planning committee after being called off the delegated list by ward councillor Stuart Currie because of the level of local concern.He said: ldquoI have called this application off the list to ensure that all the concerns raised by local residents are discussed and elected members can understand not only the strength of feeling but also the planning issues that exist as a result of this application.Musselburgh  Inveresk Community Council has lodged an objection, citing traffic congestion, emissions, and the facilityrsquos close proximity to local schools as concerns.A public campaign lsquoNo McDonaldrsquos in Musselburghrsquo was also launched in a bid to halt the plan, highlighting concerns such as increased traffic congestion, litter and air pollution.The planning report stated that there were  written representations to the application and, of these,  were objections.It said: ldquoThe councilrsquos road services advise they accept the conclusions of the traffic network modelling exercise, that the traffic impact associated with the proposed development would be minimal and there would be no adverse impact on the operation of the local highway network.ldquoMany written objections are made on the grounds of the proximity of the proposed drive-thru restaurant to Musselburgh Grammar School, and that such a facility promotes unhealthy eating and thus would lead to harmful health consequences.ldquoThe East Lothian Local Development Plan  does not contain any policies restricting the location of drive-thru restaurant facilities to a certain distance from schools, or any other educational establishments. Nor does it contain any policies relating to unhealthy eating or the health consequences of proposed developments. Thus, and in the absence of national guidance on health consequences of proposed developments, no signicant weight can be given to these matters.The report added: ldquoOn the matter of air quality, the public health and environmental protection officer advised that the proposed development was anticipated to result in up to  customer vehicles visiting the premises daily, which was a signicant number of additional vehicles given the proximity of site to the Air Quality Management Areaon Musselburgh High Street.The officer agreed with the conclusion of McDonaldrsquos Air Quality Assessment that impacts upon air quality at ldquosensitive receptors would not be signicant. The officer advised that, whilst it was acknowledged that additional traffic would have an impact upon queuing and reduce traffic speeds, the composition of the increased traffic would be from passenger cars, which are less polluting than HGVs and buses.The officer concluded that the proposed development would have ldquono harmful impact on air quality nor on the objectives of the AQMA and would not harm the amenity of the area.A McDonaldrsquos spokesperson said: ldquoWe look forward to progressing with this application and believe a new McDonaldrsquos would bring signicant investment to the local community, as well as create at least  new jobs.A supporting statement from the company added: ldquoThere are few restaurants in the country who can claim to have made so many positive changes to support healthier lestyles. McDonaldrsquos believe that the lessons they have learned in making these changes can be used to support a wider drive to reduce obesity.Planners are recommending the plan be approved with a number of conditions, including submission of litter and pest management plans.A council spokesperson declined to comment, saying the planning committee would consider the application next week.

title: letter-week-betrayal-mcdonalds-plan
story: Why obedience to the will of Tesco, the UKrsquos biggest supermarket land banking conglomerate and its aggressive alliance with the planetrsquos biggest takeaway empire  What happened to sustainability or compliance To cover themselves, council planners sought second traffic and pollution assessments. Not only will this fast food factory, with its  tables and three serving hatches, have no adverse impact on transport, parking, the environment or community amenity, it will actually solve existing problems!Thanks to  solicited reports using wizard modelling, this McDonaldrsquos will speed traffic flow by  likewise, any noise pollution on bad nights will be limited to one decibel. Phew! Advanced computer simulations prove that nitrogen dioxide and particle pollution will be ldquonegligible.The computer also says the average speed at Tesco roundabout, once this ldquoservice station opens, will be kph increasing to kph on the approaches. Yes folks, itrsquos a magic roundabout.The main report doesnrsquot quite say McDonaldrsquos is the answer to obesity and junk food addiction but comes close with descriptions of an exciting range of salads.No doubt these will feature prominently in the lunchtime ads pinged to smartphones at the Grammar from the predatory grease pit four minutes away.Teachers and PTAs remain silent because they are not free to speak but others have been less restrained. Parents, residents, our MP, MSP, Labour and SNP councillors, our community council, our area partnership and a multitude of civic groups have unanimously expressed their total opposition at .Tesco, which closed Alirsquos Cave and the last High Street butchers and fishmongers, now threatens the Caprice, other local restaurants, cafes and takeaways.Also, is Scotlandrsquos most important medieval bridge to be blighted for ever more by the ubiquitous burger symbol bathing it in a sickly neon yellow Tragically,  local objectors and , petitioners have less value than the share value of these gigantic corporations.There is no appeal: we can only trust the planning committee to halt this grotesque capitulation and betrayal.Fraser McAllisterMusselburgh

title: tour-europes-hot-spots-without-leaving-pencaitland
story: Residents and staff ndash or passengers and cabin crew ndash are recreating a European holiday, stopping off at popular hotspots on a two-month cruise ndash all without leaving Pencaitland and without getting their feet wet.Boarding passes in hand, the passengers of the Tyneholm Estate cruise liner have been enjoying the virtual holiday of a letime, exploring traditional flavours and cultures of eight faraway destinations.Captain Ann Lyell, care home manager, said that the crew were pulling out all the stops to ensure a memorable holiday.She said: ldquoNot many people would believe you can experience genuine holiday moments in a care home, but those people have never been on a Sanctuary Care Cruise.ldquoAnd this is not just a holiday for our residents, but also my team.ldquoEach week, we are bringing the European destinations into our home through amazing food, fun and inspiring excursions, and the cabin crew are playing their part perfectly.ldquoI honestly canrsquot put into words how wonderfully creative the past weeks have been, and we are all so looking forward to the rest of our European tour ndash especially our residents, some of whom have never been abroad before!ldquoWe are not only enriching lives, we are creating new le experiences ndash how amazing is that As part of the virtual cruise initiative, cabin crew are provided with weekly staff handbooks, props and supporting literature, so they can deliver traditional festivities with real authenticity.And the travel calendar is bursting at the seams, with highlights including dancing, crafting, baking, tasting, drawing, quizzing, learning and celebrating, as well as a range of festivals.Passengers and crew started off in Portugalrsquos capital city, Lisbon, and enjoyed port tasting and Azulejo tile creating at the beginning of July.The following week, the ship headed for Malaga in Spain, with Sangria making and Picasso line-drawing.Since then, the trip through the Mediterranean has continued with stops at Nice in France ndash where artists such as Claude Monet and Jean-Baptiste-Camille Corot were celebrated ndash Rome, where passengers got the chance to explore title: six-primary-schools-start-new-year-acting-headteachers
story: East Lothian Council has started the recruitment process to find new headteachers at a number of schools.At Musselburgh Burgh Primary School, Jon Doyle, depute headteacher, will step up to becoming acting headteacher.Karen Fleming retired from the role of headteacher at the end of the last school term.Mr Doyle will take on the role of acting headteacher during the recruitment process and until a new permanent headteacher is appointed.Alison Cameron, headteacher at Elphinstone Primary School, will be in charge at Humbie and Saltoun Primary Schools as well.The acting headteacher will continue to oversee the schools in Humbie and East Saltoun until a permanent headteacher is appointed.Mags McBean will also become acting headteacher at St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School in Prestonpans following the retirement of Anne Torley ahead of the summer holidays.Mrs McBean is also the headteacher at Loretto RC Primary School in Musselburgh and will lead St Gabrielrsquos RC until a permanent appointment is made.Meanwhile, at West Barns Primary School, Laura Hay, currently acting depute headteacher, will become acting headteacher.Ronnie Taylor, who was acting headteacher, willto his substantive role as headteacher of Innerwick and Stenton Primary Schools.Mrs Hay will be acting headteacher during Gill Whitfordrsquos continuing secondment within East Lothian Councilrsquos early years team.Finally, Fiona Macartney will continue with the current arrangement as acting headteacher at Whitecraig Primary School, while continuing as headteacher at Musselburghrsquos Stoneyhill Primary School.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThis will be until such time as we recruit and appoint a new headteacher for Whitecraig Primary School.

title: preston-athletic-players-swap-boots-bicycles-fundraiser

ahead of the   season.The first stop was at Millfield , before going on to Foresters Parkand New Recreation Park .The second group of cyclists ventured into Midlothian and ticked off Kingrsquos Park , title: schools-forever-former-wallyford-primary-comes
story: Edinburgh-based Kinetic Demolition was tasked with the job at the site on Salters Road, which started last month and is expected to take  weeks to complete.The school, built in , was replaced with a new pound. million primary school on the outskirts of the village on Futures Way.Mr Bathgate, a Wallyford resident and keen local historian, said the former school replaced the first village school, which dated from  and was sited next to it on Salters Road where houses now stand. The original school was demolished a few years after , he added.He said: ldquoMore classrooms were required in the s as the villagersquos population increased and the three-storey building was built to accommodate the extra pupils.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe main demolition works commenced in early July and are programmed to be completed within a -week period. title: msp-column-time-john-swinney-go
story: AS I WRITE this column at the start of the week, the SQA exam results debacle remains the dominant issue, with thousands of young people across Scotland continuing to face huge uncertainty. With over , results downgraded and pupils in the most deprived areas penalised, appeals on a scale not seen before are now predicted.Theto schools in these exceptional times will already be stressful for teachers. Add to that the tsunami of appeals that secondary teachers face having to process and there is a risk that the pressure will become overwhelming.One way to fix this would be to revert to teachersrsquo estimates for grades which have been reduced. This would show pupils in the most disadvantaged areas, who were twice as likely to have results downgraded, that their hard work will ensure they have the same chances as those in more affluent areas.I hope that is the course John Swinney takes this week. But evenhe does finally do the right thing, this is only the latest in a series of catastrophic errors made during his time as Education Secretary. In June, the late switch from his blended learning plan to a full-timeto schools left teachers and other staff only weeks to prepare.Before Covid-, the SNP said they should be judged on their record on education, but the attainment gap has hardly shted in  years. Mr Swinney was also forced to drop his ldquoflagship education bill and his standardised testing for Ps was widely condemned. He even ended Scotlandrsquos participation in two long-standing international comparison surveys because the SNP did not like the results.Given this abysmal record, it is time for Mr Swinney to be held accountable for his failings and go. I hope that by the time this column is published, we will have a new Education Secretary.

title: msp-column-the-sqa-got-one-wrong
story: THEto school after the summer holidays is always a momentous occasion, especially for those starting primary school or transitioning to secondary.I still recall my children heading off for the first time, as well as setting off myself to high school.The former is a tender moment for every parent and the latter is daunting for every child.Theyrsquore a le milestone, but especially so this year.Coronavirus has been traumatic for all: young people whose education has been disrupted, parents whorsquove had to adjust to having them at home and assisting in their schooling, and teachers who have had to adapt to a changed world.Preparing tohas also been hard, given late notice and the restrictions required to battle Covid-.It has been frustrating for pupils and parents but the staff at council and in schools deserve enormous thanks for their efforts.It was never going to be easy and therersquoll be issues along the way, with perhaps even further changes needed to be made.But wersquore in a new world and thatrsquos only to be expected. Allowances will have to be made for that and support given, not just criticism made of staff and officials struggling to adjust.What matters most is getting the young folk back into school ndash not only for their educational development but the socialisation that goes along with it.For some, therersquoll be additional issues over examinations. The SQA has got this one wrong.Anything that discriminates against those from the most deprived backgrounds is perverse and those best placed to judge during these exceptional times are the teachers whorsquove been supervising them.Too many young people have been disadvantaged for it to be addressed solely by inidual appeals. This is a systemic failure and wider change must follow.It seems that Parliament is going to ensure that and in the interim I have made it clear to headteachers Irsquoll be prepared to support them in appeals theyrsquore making on pupilsrsquo behalf.

title: column-wild-camping-issues
story: OKAY, I feel I should apologise for this one up front.Those of you expecting the usual guide to this monthrsquos wildle will be disappointed, Irsquom afraid.Instead, what Irsquod like to do is to take a look at an issue facing many areas in East Lothianrsquos countryside.As many of you will be aware, wild camping is a pastime that seems to be gaining popularity, perhaps as a result of peoplersquos understandable need to get out and about after long months of lockdown.Unfortunately, this can sometimes have a detrimental impact on the environment.In Scotland, the right to wild camp is enshrined in law, although as with all access rights, this comes along with responsibilities.The Scottish Outdoor Access Codeoutlines our access rights and responsibilities, including those pertaining to camping.One of the main problems is that any discussion involves terms such as ldquoresponsible access and ldquowild camping itself, but people interpret these terms dferently.Generally speaking, wild camping should be lightweight and short-term ndash one or two tents for no more than two or three nights.Wild campers should also follow the lsquoLeave No Tracersquo philosophy. Essentially, this means there should be no way of telling yoursquove been there ndash no litter, no signs of fires, no damage to trees or other elements of the environment.This is a good example of wild campingSome very conscientious campers take this further by removing litter left by others, i.e. the site looks better for them having been there. Hats off to these heroes.If it can sometimes be dficult to define what wild camping is, itrsquos easier to say what it isnrsquot.It isnrsquot pitching a tent in a car park, and it certainly isnrsquot turning up with your entire family and friends and a car full of glamping kit and or lager.It may also surprise some people, but responsible wild camping would not include an open fire at least not in certain areas. SOAC states that you should ldquonever light an open fire during prolonged dry periods or in areas such as forests, woods, farmland... So, fires in the woods are in breach of the code, as are fires anywhere during dry periods.If yoursquore desperately in need of a fire, the place to have it is on the beach.Itrsquos also a good idea to bring your own wood. Collecting fuel on-site isnrsquot a good thing, as dead wood is a valuable part of ecosystems. Cutting branches from trees may constitute vandalism and anyway, green wood burns really badly.Perhaps itrsquos also important to think about the ethos behind wild camping.As mentioned, truly wild camping should have an intrinsic respect for, and minimal impact on, the natural environment.At some of our sites, wersquove seen a huge increase in camping in recent years.Many of those involved are reasonably responsible campers, fires aside, that is, leaving little or no litter.However, the cumulative effect of such a high density of campersis to slowly degrade the natural environment.Then, of course, therersquos the issue of where all these people are going to the toilet, but letrsquos not dwell on that.So, perhaps it just needs a little more thought on the part of the campers.Some sites are simply inappropriate ndash Aberlady Bay and Traprain Law, for example, being a nature reserve and scheduled monument respectively.Others may be OK sometimes, but not when busy.Under these circumstances, it may be that prospective campers should think about choosing another venue.Right, rant over normal service will be resumed next month.

title: tims-tales-clifftop-castle-tales
story: I have always wanted to visit it, but never seemed to get the opportunity then suddenly, a day of sunny weather last week combined with some free time made a trip possible.The walk to the castle was stunning, with purple heather-clad braes and a sparkling sea. To add to the magic, we saw dolphins as we approached the ruins.There is actually little left of the castle itself: small chunks of masonry jutting out like broken teeth are the only obvious evidence to the existence of the clf-top fortress.But itrsquos the location, and the stories attached to it, which tingle the spine.Itrsquos a steep descent to it, and care needs to be taken as you near the castle, for the path veers dangerously close to the edge of the clfs.We took it gradually, with a distant view of the ruins enticing us. A solid cement walkway now links the promontory to the mainland, where once a drawbridge gave access to the castle. The kids crossed it, one by one, with help from me and my we Kate. Itrsquos at this point, as you enter the historic remains, that the power of the location is truly revealed.Itrsquos like walking into lsquothe godsrsquo of a giant natural amphitheatre, with clfs looming on both sides, and sheer drops below. The sound of the open sea and gulls swamp your senses, and I was thankful we had visited when it was calm, for I can imagine a visit on a windy day would give the precipitous edges an almost terrying character. We settled down for our picnic where once the great hall stood, with breathtaking views.Whenever I visit such places, itrsquos not just what is seen that inspires me itrsquos the stories of the place. Here the ghosts of the past wait to tell you their tale,you have an ear to listen. And what tales are sewn onto this rocky top!The castle gets its first mention in the early s, but for sure human habitation predates that. In , the English captured it and it remained in English hands for the rest of that century a stone in the shoe of south-east Scotland. It was finally retaken in  by the forces of Patrick Dunbar but later it became a rebuilt stronghold of the Home family.History records that they hosted the young princess Margaret Tudor here in  as she headed north to become Scotlandrsquos queen, with her marriage to James IV and thus change the destiny of both countries.She will have shared the views we had while we ate our picnic, although I suspect her banquet may have been a little more indulgent. Who can say what impressions this wild view gave her of her new homeland.Her granddaughter, Mary Queen of Scots, would visit the castle  years later in , in what for her was a very turbulent time.How I wished the few stones of the castle that still stood could tell a story of these remarkable women, who had to navigate their royal privilege through misogynist contempt.After being abandoned, the castlersquos windswept ruins were the haunt of smugglers and wreckers, who would set a light amongst the old stones, making it look like a welcoming port.But it was the story of Madge Gordon that was foremost in my mind as I sat amongst the ruins of the castle that, according to the tale, she helped liberate from the English.The story is called the lsquoGuid We of Coldinghamrsquo and it is to be found in Wilsonrsquos Tales of the Borders. These were a fantastic collection of stories written by John Mackay Wilson in the early th century. Today, the Wilsonrsquos Tales Project promotes his work, which was prodigious.It is a tale set in the grim times of the Rough Wooing in the s, when English forces were using force and terror to persuade the Scots to agree to the marriage of the young Mary Queen of Scots to Edward Tudor.Madge was a widow with an abiding hatred of the English occupiers, who had killed her husband. Her daughter Janet was in love with a young man called Florence, but Madge would only agree to their marriagethe young man showed his loyalty and mettle by helping her to take Fast Castle, which had been occupied by English forces.This he agreed to do, and raised a force of over a hundred local people. Madge hatched a plan to attack the castle, but both she and Florence kept it secret from Janet. She feared for her loversquos le, and felt strongly that war was pointless for it mattered not who occupied the castle as the poor folk would be oppressed either way.Madge led the attack, entering the castle in the guise of being a seller of local produce, then plunging her husbandrsquos sword into a guard. The ensuing fight was short and brutal. The young Florence fought bravely and the castle was won.After this, Madge proudly agreed that the brave Florence was worthy of her daughterrsquos hand in marriage. Janet, who had heard the commotion of the fight and rushed to the scene, desperately looked for her Florence.When she saw he was alive, she rushed joyfully to him and held him in a tight embrace. He held her likewise, saying her name ldquoJanet.But this was to be his last word spoken, for his hold on her began to weaken and his legs gave way. He had been mortally wounded in the fight. Janet screamed for help and he was carried into a room in the castle, where frantic attempts to revive him were made but he was gone.Janet plunged into inconsolable grief. She blamed her mother, and the unbearable loss sent her to the grave only two years later. Her mother followed the year after, and all three rest in Coldingham kirkyard.ldquoWhat a sad story, my we said after I had finished telling it. ldquoIs it true ldquoMaybe not in the sense you mean, I said, ldquobut it is a story with real truth: how war spawns hatred and loss, and as Janet said, the poor folk lose out whoever rules the castle.On such a sunny day, it was dficult to leave this beautul place, but the kids wanted a swim and the sun was already lowering in the sky.The walk back is a hard slog up the brae, but it gives moments to rest and catch your breath while turning to view the ruins.Here, surrounded by millions of years of geology, with the view of the tumbled remains of a castle in which lives now long forgotten were lived, a whisper is heard in the wind.ldquoWhatever your woes, whatever your joys, yours is a tiny speck in time, so use it wisely and with gratitude.On that day, I think we did just that.

title: msp-column-ensuring-river-esk-remains-clean
story: For too long now, the river has been a point of concern for many of my constituents, and I wanted to start a forum where it would bring together those who are working to clean the river, as well as those from the community with an interest in the river, so that we could all work together to find a resolution.In my view, it is important that we look at the cleanliness of the river as a whole, tackling the issues from the sewage spillages and the coal mine discharge in Midlothian, right down to the poor water quality at Fisherrow.The meeting was productive and I am looking forward to seeing progress on this matter. If yoursquod like to be kept in the loop with what ERIG are doing, please contact me at colin.beattie.msp@parliament.scot and I can add you to our mailing list.I would like to wish all those ing to school this week all the best in the academic year. We should all be especially grateful to the teachers who have made this possible and are working in unprecedented times, overcoming new challenges, in order to ensure that our children receive their education in a safe environment. I know that many may have anxieties about theirto school however, the Scottish Government is closely monitoring matters to ensure that our children and communities are kept safe.August  will mark the th anniversary of VJ Day, where Japan surrendered in the Second World War, bringing an end to the war. We pay tribute to all those who lost their lives and remember those who fought to protect the peace which we have today. There are many online commemorations marking VJ Day, and I hope that my constituents can get involved in marking this important occasion.

title: column-east-lothians-railways
story: At least the Gford and Garvald Railway had coal freight to sustain it. But a coastal branch line didnrsquot even have that fallback. By the s, golf and seaside holidays were booming in resorts. With only horse-drawn transport available, Aberlady and Gullane both felt disadvantaged without access by train.So the Aberlady, Gullane and North Berwick Railway was launched as a private venture in . It soon ran into problems.Landowners denied access, requiring a detour, putting Aberlady station half a mile from the village. NBR fought any extension past Gullane to avoid competing with their own line from Drem.Such problems delayed opening until April , , when a service of nine trains a day ran between Longniddry, which had three s, and the Haddington branch. Trains ran one and a half miles to a junction at Spittal, where the line curved north, then veered east to what is now Aberlady Caravan Park. The track bed has been ed to farmland, but incongruous over-bridges on the Ballencrieff and Fenton roads mark where it once ran.Just north of the Peffer Burn, a wooden  was added in  for the exclusive use of Luffness Golf Club members. It then ran north-east on what is now the John Muir Way to its only level crossing at Saltcoats Farm, then on to a single  at Gullane, at the aptly named Muirfield Station. The nearby former fire training school was built as the Marine Hotel for use by golfers.The line lost money. Buses soon lured away passengers by the s, so service ended in . The line was kept open to ship local sugar beet to Cupar for processing, but even that ended in .The line does have little-known claims to fame: when King George VI visited Scotland during the Second World War, his royal train was parked here as a safe location in , drivers were trained on their new diesel multiple units on this soon-to-become Beeching branch line casualty.If only NBR had foresight to build the ECML direct through Tranent and Haddington to East Linton, they could have built a truly scenic Lothian Coast Railway from Musselburgh to North Berwick ndash and ALL towns and villages between.

title: happy-ormiston-couple-toast-70th-wedding-anniversary
story: Jenny and Harry Runciman celebrated their th wedding anniversary at their home on George Crescent.The couple married in Pencaitland Parish Church on August , . They had their wedding reception in Ormiston Church Hall as people were not allowed alcohol in Pencaitlandrsquos church hall.They were married before  guests, with the high number coming from Jennyrsquos previous job in the local Co-op store.Jenny, , from Pencaitland, met -year-old Harry, from Ormiston, at the dancing at Pencaitland Village Hall. However, Harry knew Jenny for quite some time before they started courting.As well as being conscripted as a paratrooper in the Second World War, during his working le Harry worked in construction and for the local council in East Lothian in the highways department and in environmental health as an administrator he was also an administrator for companies such as the coalboard and Bairdrsquos Malt in Pencaitland, Harryrsquos last job before he retired.Jenny worked in Co-operative stores in both Pencaitland and Ormiston, and made school dinners for children at Ormiston Primary School, so the couple are well known by people in both villages.After Jenny and Harry married they had three children, David, Tommy and Linda. The couple also have six grandchildren and five great grandchildren.Jenny and Harry were said to be excellent bowlers and very keen and interested in the sport they also enjoyed tennis and were keen gardeners.The couple, who say they get on really well and have done everything together, also loved dancing and continued to do so in Tranentrsquos Co-operative Bowling Club until recent times.However, the pair are now unable to get out much and sadly unable to do the sports and activities they once enjoyed.They do, however, enjoy short walks down their street and across to the bowling club when they can.Son David said his parents were still just as in love as ever, adding that Jenny and Harry did not want to make a big fuss of the day and did not want to have a party so are instead going out for a family meal to The Longniddry Inn.David said his parents coped well during lockdown and had been very careful due to their age.The couple are still able to live relatively independently, with a cleaner visiting the house once a week or so.Alongside his sister Linda, he visits his parents every couple of days to check in.The couple get deliveries of Wiltshire Farm Foodsrsquo microwavable ready meals. Linda will also pick up items for them as they are needed.David said: ldquoThey lost contact with their great grandkids [over lockdown] but we couldnrsquot risk sending them into the house in case they passed anything on.ldquoUsually we would have all the family roundwe could but first of all they would struggle to keep up with it all.The couple were looking forward to receiving another card from the Queen they previously received one for their th wedding anniversary.

title: blooming-haddington-receive-5-000-boost
story: Haddingtonrsquos horticultural volunteers were given pound, through Common Good funding, with the cash being used to buy  hanging baskets for the town centre.The money, which was approved by councillors under East Lothian Councilrsquos emergency recess arrangements, will also go towards purchasing planters, boxes and compost.Joe Forte, vice-chairman of Blooming Haddington, which represented Scotland in last yearrsquos Britain in Bloom, said: ldquoWe are very appreciative of the support. title: east-lothians-six-childrens-hubs-close-summer-holidays
story: More than  staff helped support the hubs through the summer holidays after switching from their normal roles to support the emergency measures.East Lothian Council openedsix hubs across its main towns, reducing them to four during school holidays as required.The council said the hubs not only supported key workers and carers but also vulnerable children and those with complex needs.Staff from schools, nurseries, library services, countryside rangers and more offered to help run the hubs, providing for hundreds of youngsterswho attended.During the summer, senior pupils from secondary schools were also able to help out.Monica Patterson, council chief executive, said: ldquoIrsquod like to thank staff from across the council and our partners who did such a fantastic job in initially establishing and then maintaining the hubs, including provision during school holidays.ldquoI recognise that a huge amount of planning, preparation and day-to-day support has been provided and Irsquom pleased that this has benefited many families by enabling key worker parents and carers to continue working, while continuing to support children and young people with complex additional support needs.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet spokesperson for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoI know that many parents and carers have valued the support provided by our childrenrsquos hubs since March.ldquoPutting emergency learning and childcare in place was incredibly supportive, and we couldnrsquot have done it without the hard work and commitment of so many staff from across a number of dferent teams and services across the council and from some of our partners.

title: children-left-without-water-school-rules-confusion
story: Confusion over new guidelines introduced across East Lothian schools as youngsters ed saw children in some schools told they could not refill their personal water bottles unless there was a tap in their classroom.It meant that by lunchtime on Wednesday, as temperatures soared into the mid s across East Lothian, a number of children had emptied their bottles.Parents took to social media with reports of primary school children collected from school parched and complaining of headaches after they were told they could not get more water.One mother revealed that her nine-year-old son was refused a chance to refill his bottle after running out of water in the morning and told he could not leave his desk, which was directly under a window with the sun streamingin.She said: "If this was a prison and inmates were refused access to water in the heat there would be an outcry, so why were our children treated like this "Campaigning group Us For Them Scotland later named three East Lothian schools - Musselburgh Grammar School, Haddington Primary School and Campie Primary School in Musselburgh -among a list of Scottish schools where there had been complaints about children being refused access to water.East Lothian Council said that access to water was available in all schools and schools had been given further clarication on the guidelines.A spokesperson said: "Access to drinking water is available in all of our schools."We are encouraging all families to send their child to school with a ready-filled water bottle ndash families were advised to contact their school in advancethere would be an issue providing one."Refill opportunities are available, with the most appropriate method having been determined by inidual schools to best meet their setting. This means all children have access to drinking water."Our schools have put a huge amount of work into a safefor all children and young people, and will continue to monitor how well their arrangements are working."We have worked with our schools to clary guidance and put in place measures that will make sure all children and young people have opportunities to top-up drinking water throughout the day."Parents on social media said their children had also been unable to access water yesterday.One parentsaid: "This also happened to my son today, who came home and said he was so thirsty he felt light-headed."Another local added: "My two grandsons said the same when we picked them up, both were gasping on a drink. My daughters sending them with extra water bottles tomorrow."Other parents said that the problem occured at a number of schools, pointing out that some children attended breakfast clubs and after-school clubs, meaning even with an extra bottle they had to make it last for nine hours.Another asked of teaching staff: "If you can grab a takeaway latte from Costa, why cant they refill the wee ones water bottles "However, others defended the teaching staff, pointing out that emails to parents had made those whose children would not be able to refill water bottles during the day aware and that schools were "on a learning curve" with new ways of working.At Campie Primary School in Musselburgh, where concerns were also raised on Wednesday, it is understood that teachers went round the classrooms with jugs of fresh water in the afternoon and planned to do that again.Us For Them Scotland organiser Johannah Bisset said: "Even cattle have a legal right to water. Yet somehow our children have had that right stripped away from them.ldquoThis decision once again demonstrates the utter disregard these decision-makers have for the wellbeing of our children."Children all over Scotland are writing to the First Minister to ask her to provide water for all of Scotlandrsquos children. We have great hopes that she will respond positively to protect our children."

title: property-patter-give-home-facelift-budget---living-room-bedroom
story: But in part  of our lsquoHow to give your home a facelt on a budgetrsquo, wersquore going to give you some great ideas to update your bedrooms, living room and even hallway.BedroomsWhen it comes to styling your bedroom, the best way to inject some colour and style, whilst keeping costs down, is to add it through your accessories. Keep your wall colours neutral, like white and grey, but use your curtains, bedding and cushions to inject splashes of colour.Buying new bedding and hanging a new set of curtains can cost a lot less than a few tins of paint once you factor in all the rollers and brushes yoursquoll need to buy, plus it will take less time too.Once yoursquove bought the cushions, next time yoursquore thinking about changing the colour, just buy new covers and match the size of the cushions. That means you can store the others away, pass them on to a friend or use them in another room.Donrsquot forget about artwork. You can find some really trendy prints online and IKEA is great for cheap frames too. Make sure you buy the same size prints each time, meaning you can keep the same frames. You can update the frames easily too with a cheap can of spray paint.Canrsquot afford a new carpet  Yoursquoll be amazed at what a good deep clean and adding a colourful or patterned rug can do.If your furniture is looking a bit tired, upcycle with a lick of paint and new door handles. You can pick up a tin of furniture paint from most hardware stores or online and you can buy cute, quirky doorknobs from eBay or Etsy, or even just try spray painting the existing ones.Metal accessories like curtain rods and light fittings can benefit from that spray paint too!Upcycling is a great way to keep costs low, give a much loved item a new lease of le and is good for the environment by cutting out waste.Living roomMoving on to the most used room in the house, this can be the most dficult to update as it no doubt has many uses. From the TV room to the playroom to the dining room, your living space probably needs to be more practical than anything . But you can still add some style along the way.Your sofa likely dominates the room and can be the most expensive piece in the room ndash with the exception of the TV! So replacing this often can be costly. But have you considered replacing the covers  If your sofa is in generally good condition but itrsquos looking a bit off-colour, you can buy covers that fit over the top.IKEA do a range of these covers that are made for their sofa ranges, but you can find places online that offer made to measure services. This can be more expensive, but definitely cheaper than buying a whole new sofa and are machine washable! Alternatively, adding a new throw and some scatter cushions can have the same effect.Many of the tips for the bedroom can be used in the living room too. Like adding a nice feature wall for a splash of colour or why not try adding a nice gallery wall with lots of family pictures  A great way to add a personal touch to a room. You can even get the family involved to pick out their favourite pictures.Plants are a great way to brighten up a room and fill any unused corners. Donrsquot worry, it doesnrsquot mean another mouth to feed, there are plenty of really great looking fake ones to buy.Have you tried shopping from other rooms in your house  Yoursquod be surprised at how much you can change your rooms by simply swapping the accessories about.HallwayTherersquos nothing nicer than a warm welcome so donrsquot forget your hallway when yoursquore giving your home a makeover.If itrsquos on the small size then good advice is to keep it nice and bright to give the illusion of space and add colour by adding some prints to the wall, some useful hanging hooks and even a funky doormat.Everything in your hallway needs to have a practical use, but that doesnrsquot mean it has to be boring.You can add plants here too butyoursquore limited on floor space, why not try some hanging baskets or small potted plants on shelves.Maybe go the extra mile and paint the doors in your hallway  This trend is becoming more popular, with people opting for painting their doors and skirting boards, from pink to yellow and even black.Hopefully, these tips have given you some DIY inspiration to give your home a little low-cost makeover.

title: online-edinburgh-festival-12-must-see-shows-events
story: Thats exactly what has happened.You cant generally hit pause and play at the same time, but the Edinburgh Festival has managed it for its  iteration, with a rich, brave and pioneering programme of mostly digital and online events with here and there a visual treat for capital residents and those tourists who have decided to come anyway.The theatres may be dark but, as the programme makes clear, the artistic light burns bright regardless.My Light Shines On DisplayAs well as being the umbrella title for much of the digital offering from this yearrsquos Edinburgh International Festivalndash Kirsty Wark fronts the programme, which features a performance by Scottish Chamber Orchestra cellist Su-a Lee ndash My Light Shines On is also a light display project which will illuminate the cityrsquos famous festival venues.Using beacons of light which will be visible from vantage points across the capital it has been created by Scottish lighting designers Kate Bonney and Simon Hayes, the duo behind Pitlochryrsquos Enchanted Forest and the Electric Glen in East Renfreshire.The inspiration is the tradition of the so-called lsquoghost lightrsquo in which a light is left on in a theatre even when the venue is lsquodarkrsquo, as all theatres currently are. Andyoursquore wondering about where title came from, itrsquos a line from Primal Screamrsquos  song Movinrsquo On Up.www.e whats-on  mylightshinesonDeclanA companion piece, of sorts, to the Traverse Theatrersquos  hit Mouthpiece, written by Kieran Hurley and a keen dissection of class and culture in the capital.Here, Mouthpiece actor Lorn Macdonald turns director to re-work the two-hander in order to concentrate on the character he played, the titular Declan, a -year-old aspiring artist.Using footage shot on the Edinburgh streets plus animation and elements of the Mouthpiece script, he fleshes out Declanrsquos le and experiences. The resulting film forms part of the Traverse Digital Festival  and will be available to watch on demand later in the month.From August www.traverse declanEdinburgh International Book FestivalThe Booker Prize-winning author of Girl, Woman, Other recently became the first British woman of colour to top the UK paperback fiction chart and in the wake of the murder of George Floyd therersquos a sharp topicality to her novel, which follows the lives of  mostly black women across the years.In this special event, to be broadcast from the Edinburgh International Book Festivalrsquos Edinburgh studio, she discusses her work with the First Minister, who has written warmly about Eisto and is no stranger to the book festival  herself. Doubtless there will also be some chat about the topic occupying Ms Sturgeonrsquos time during her day job, the ongoing public health emergency caused by coronavirus.The event is free to watch online though registration is required for anybody who wants to ask a question through the QAor to participate in the chatroom. Andyou miss the event, it and most of the many other author events will remain online for the duration of the book festival.August , .pmwww.edbookfestLes Amazones DrsquoAfrique: A Virtual Live PerformanceAn lsquoas liversquo gig by musical powerhouse Les Amazones DrsquoAfrique, the multi-lingual, politically conscious all-female collective who blend hip-hop and RB with the traditional sounds of their Malian homeland.A bona fide supergroup ndash a founding member is Mariam Doumbia of Amadou  Mariam, and regular helpmates include the great Angeacutelique Kidjo ndash the band released their second album, Amazones Power, to great acclaim earlier this year and are bringing through an army of young talent in their wake.Part of the My Light Shines On strand, you can watch the band on the EIFrsquos dedicated YouTube channel from .pm on August .August  onwardswww.youtube user edinburghintfestivalEdinburgh Art FestivalEdinburghrsquos thoroughfares will this year bedevoid of crowds, buskers and whatever you call those people who persistently thrust flyers under your nose, but the special vibe of the festival streets is being re-created to an extent by an array of outdoor interventions from the Edinburgh Art Festivalas part of its Around The City strand.EAF favourite Peter Liversidge has recreated his  project Flags For Edinburgh ndash  flags saying HELLO will fly from buildings across the capital ndash and where there are billboard-mounted artistic interventions both whimsical and political. Keep your eyes peeled.Various venueswww.edinburghartfestivalFringe On FridayRunning on Fridays throughout what would have been the Edinburgh Fringe, this paid-for,  minute iety style show-cum-fundraiser gives you a slice of what might have been.The virtual curtain goes up at pm, tickets cost poundand among the acts confirmed so far are David OrsquoDoherty, Lost Voice Guy and Tf Stevenson.From August www.edfringeChamber Music Soundscapes In Princes Street GardensEvery weekday at pm from Monday the EIF will mount a live concert featuring a range of top chamber musicians, the only dference from normal festival fare being that the musicians will be in The Hub, EIFrsquos headquarters at the top of the Royal Mile, and the audience will be in Princes Street Gardens listening via an array of speakers .Among the musicians lined up to play are members of the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra , the Elias String Quartet , the Dunedin Consortand, kicking things off on Monday, tenor Nicky Spence and pianist Malcolm Martineau performing Shakespearean Songs. As ever, you can watch on the EIF YouTube channel.August -, Princes Street Gardenswww.e whats-on  chambermusicprincesstreetgardenswww.youtube user edinburghintfestivalDouglas StuartShuggie Bain, Douglas Stuartrsquos searing tale about a desolate childhood in Thatcherrsquos Glasgow, has been longlisted for the Booker Prize ndash not bad for a debut novel, even one which took its author  years to complete.Here, the Glasgow-born writer and former menswear designer talks to fellow Scot Damian Barr about growing up gay on a Glasgow housing scheme, his unlikely hero Shuggie Bain and the prospect of literary fame.Featuring as part of the Edinburgh International Book Festivalrsquos Made In Scotland series, the event is free to watch online though registration is required for anybody who wants to ask a question through the QAor to participate in the chatroom.August , .pmwww.edbookfestGhost LightScreening as part of the EIFrsquos My Light Shines On strand, this collaborative film by Edinburgh-based director Hope Dickson Leach and the National Theatre of Scotlandrsquos artistic director Jackie Wylie features a cast which includes James McArdle, Siobhaacuten Redmond, Thierry Mabonga and Anna Russell-Martin.Described as a love letter to Scottish theatre it draws on work by writers such as JM Barrie, David Greig, Rona Munro and Jackie Kay, as well as original compositions by Glasgow-based singer-songwriter Patricia Panther.From August www.e whats-on  nts-ghostlightwww.youtube user edinburghintfestivalAn Evening With Scottish BalletNo EIF programme would be complete without a rich menu of dance to choose from and as often as not the national company is one of those helping to provide it.And so it is in , though Scottish Balletrsquos contribution to the My Light Shines On strand is made up of a series of filmed pieces drawing on old workand existing filmed work .But the showstopper is a world premiere in the form of Catalyst, created by Scottish Ballet soloist Nicholas Shoesmith and performed on the stage of theFestival Theatre. The entire programme is available to view online from .pm on August .From August www.e whats-on  scottishballet-filmwww.youtube user edinburghintfestivalHilary MantelIn this book festival event, filmed at Mantelrsquos home in England, arts journalist Charlotte Higgins talks to the double Booker Prize winner about The Mirror And The Light, the third and final instalment in her trilogy of works about politickingth century English lawyer Thomas Cromwell.Wolf Hall and Bringing Up The Bodies are both award-winning bestsellers and nobodyrsquos betting against Mantel picking up a third Booker for The Mirror And The Light when the winner is announced in September. The event is free to watch online.August , .pmwww.edbookfestEdinburgh Festival Chorus: Carmina BuranaThe festival wouldnrsquot be the festival without the massed voices of Edinburgh Festival Chorus booming out from the choir stalls of the Usher Hall.Here the -strong choir performs two movements from Carl Orffrsquos much-loved work ndash O Fortuna and Ecce Gratum ndash though each member has rehearsed, performed and recorded their part in their own home.The resulting audio and visual material has been mixed by a sound engineer and film editor and turned into a sort of choral mosaic. It should be no less impressive as a result. The film is available to watch from .pm on August From August www.e whats-on  chorus-carminaburanawww.youtube user edinburghintfestival

title: property-patter-make-home-feel-bigger-simple-tricks
story: Although this may have been a temporary measure, you might find that you need some extra, permanent, space in your existing home.With some imagination and a surprisingly small budget, yoursquoll be amazed at what you can achieve without having to up sticks and move.StorageDo you have the room space but just too much stuff  For starters, it sounds obvious, but do a big clear out. With recycling centres and charity shops open again therersquos no excuse. Spend the weekend sorting through any unwanted items and donate where you can.For storage solutions, you need to think outside the box ndash literally. Vacuum bags are ideal, they normally come in multipacks of ious sizes and are really cheap. Great for anything soft that is taking up a lot of space. Winter clothes, quilts and blankets can be reduced to a tenth of the size and slide under the bed nicely.If floor space is a problem, then the sky is the limit, literally. Consider storing items that arenrsquot needed on a regular basis above units or wardrobes. Think about shelving units that are tall and slim, rather than long and bulky.Cheap and cheerful plastic, canvas or cardboard boxes can help to keep everything in place while adding a splash of colour and style. Perfect for keeping clutter off the floor.Shelves above radiators are a great way to use otherwise wasted space.If the kids are desperate for some space, a reading nook or kids study area can easily be achieved under the stairs or a window. A simple storage box with a couple of cushions on top will create a comfy seat and can double up as extra storage.Hooks can be attached to pretty much anything like bedroom doors and inside cupboards ndash again keeping items off the floor will create the illusion of more space. In the kitchen, using hooks to hang pots and pans and magnets for knives can free up cupboard space and make a statement.Knowing where things are is half the battle when considering storage options, so think about clear plastic boxes or bags that are easy to see into and can be labelled.Flexible furniture like extendable dining tables, sofa beds and even clothes rails are ideal as they have multiple uses and can be stored away easily when not in use.Let there be lightLighting and mirrors are your friends when it comes to making a smaller room feel bigger. Change large floor lamps for smaller wall lights and when it comes to wall colour, stick to pale colours and swap out heavy curtains with blinds. Luckily, a big tub of value white paint goes a long way. Let in as much light as possible, give the windows a good scrub and update yellowing lightbulbs to bright white.OutdoorsIs it time to rethink that huge sofa set and professional sized goal posts  When buying furniture, think small, light and foldable so that they can be stored away in a shed or cupboard or easily moved around. Updating your garden furniture doesnrsquot need to cost the earth, yoursquoll find some really great bargain sets in supermarkets like Aldi, Asda and Tesco and homeware stores like BM.Another way to make it feel bigger is to simply give it a good tidy. Yoursquoll be surprised at how much space you do have after clearing out those unwanted flowerpots, cutting the grass and trimming back the hedges.Your home is an investment, to be enjoyed for a long time and with these simple but effective ideas, you can enjoy the space you have for longer.

title: new-bbc-documentary-series-jamie-genevieve-great-indoors-air-week
story: The make-up artist, who is a worldwide star on YouTube and Instagram, will star in the three-part series Jamie Genevieve: Great Indoors on BBC Scotland onThursday at . pm.It comes after the success of her first documentary for the networks BBC Scotland channel Jamie Genevieve #Unfiltered.The former Cathkin High School pupil started out working in make-up counters in Debenhams in Glasgow.Now she is known for her how to make-up demonstrations on YouTube.The new mini-series focuses on how Jamie and husband Jack is coping in the middle of the coronavirus pandemic from trying her hand at hairdressing to baking.

title: we-lost-dad-cant-mum-yet-p-k-thinks-can-drive-269-miles-babysitter-glasgow-reacts-dominic-cummings
