UK-wide day of action highlighting the urgent government help the sector needs during the covid- crisis.The live events industry across the UK will come together, at pm on Tuesday, August  to host a series of creative action to help save the live events and entertainment sector which is on the verge of collapsing without financial support from the government.Hundreds of venues are expected to turn their lights red in more than  cities across the UK to symbolise the industry going into Red Alert.In Wales, in excess of  venues and events businesses have signed up to turn red to stress the need for support.MORE STORIESWelsh Government aims to secure the future of Wales culture sectorWales Millennium Centre in Cardf Bay will close until at least January The show must go on - says owner of Waless smallest theatre, The Small Space, BarryA large collective from the industry made up of trade bodies, businesses, freelancers and venue staff, currently on furlough, will gather in groups of no more than in front of each venue to support the #WeMakeEvents #LightItInRed campaign.Wales-based events companies will light up their trucks as they lay empty on forecourts.Welsh venues confirmed to turning red are the Motorpoint Arena, Cardf Castle, Principality Stadium, City Hall, Wales Millennium Centre, New Theatre, Chapter, St Davidrsquos Hall, venues in Womanby Street, USW Atrium, Dolman Theatre, ICC Wales.Sarah Hemsley-Cole, director of SC Productions Ltd, an events production company based in Cardf said: ldquoCovid- has had a devastating effect on the live events and arts sector here in Wales, not only our theatres, but our touring shows, stadium shows, live music venues and outdoor arts have been decimated by the pandemic.ldquoThe ecosystem of our creative industry ndash skilled professional such as technicians, designers, actors, performers, musicians and suppliers are now fighting for survival."In Wales alone there are in excess of  iniduals employed within the creative industries, and with the governments furlough scheme ending in October, and with no sense of a time line when events and venues can re-open ndash many are being forced in to poverty debt and despondency.ldquoWith no timeline or criteria having been issued by the Welsh Government for their administration of the cultural recovery fund, unlike the Welsh Arts Council who have released their timeline for applications, this delay will leave the whole industry extremely vulnerable and at risk of extinction.ldquoWe urgently need the financial support across the creative industries extended, we need support now in order to support anyone and everyone from falling through the cracks, and we need grants not loans for the supply chain.ldquoAll live events, including sporting events, provide both a massive part of many peoplersquos social calendar and a huge amount of employment.ldquoThe call to action hopes to raise awareness for over a million professionals at risk of losing their jobs, , of whom deliver outdoor events, around  per cent of the workforce are freelance.ldquoThe imminent closure of the self-employed income support scheme at the end of the month threatens their livelihood.ldquoUnlike other industries, events, festivals, and performances have been unable to safely reopen due to social distancing guidance and may not reopen until early  ndash and opening times keep being pushed back.ldquoWith no government support on the horizon for the event supply chain, redundancies have already begun, research indicates that  per cent of companies will have served redundancy notices by end of August, this rises to  per cent by the end of December.Cardf Motorpoint Arena managing director, Phil Sheeran added: ldquoThis isnrsquot just about our venues and the staff specically associated with them.ldquoNor just about the companies directly involved in live events.ldquoThis is also about the hotels and their staff where fans stay pre and post concerts.ldquoRestaurants, bars and pubs where for lots of concert goers the evening begins.ldquoTaxis, bus companies, trains and even airlines.ldquoProbably every business in a city like Cardf benefits in some way or another from the economic impact of the live events industry at whatever venue size you can think of.ldquoThe risk is huge for many, many people and sectors.ldquoWe need to get back to work without restrictions.ldquoIf that cannot happen then the support mechanisms like furlough, grants ndash not loans, and an extension to the self-employment scheme must be continued.More Others built roads and bridges."TheBurma-Thailand railway was nicknamed, lsquoDeath Railwayrsquo, after , prisoners of war and , local labourers died constructing its path."The allied civilians living in the Far East were captured and interned in camps, where women, children and men were subjected to similarly brutal conditions."For all those who survived ndash military and civilians - the wounds of war were etched firmly in their psyche for good."After the joy of Victory in Europeday, we can only imagine the courage and fortitude of those who remained at war for another three long months."The Welsh troops serving in the Far East and Pacic faced conditions theyrsquod never even heard of before."In extreme heat, in monsoons, alongside mosquitos and facing tropical disease, their battle was quite extraordinary."Collaboration with allies was key to success. Indian, Myanmarese, Nepali and troops from across the African continent, led the effort in South East Asia with Australian, New Zealand, Pacic Islanders, US and Canadians in the South West and Central Pacic."Many other nations also contributed."Around  per cent of personnel of the main army in South East Asia ndash the th Army - hailed from modern day India, Pakistan and Bangladesh."The contribution of volunteers across the nations was staggering. The Indian Army, had grown to . million members by the end of the war, making it the largest volunteer army in history."After the elation of VE day, some Welsh troops who survived the Far East felt like the lsquoForgotten Armyrsquo."They had served so far away, cut off from their loved ones and any contact with the world they had known."The focus at home had firmly been on Europe they could be forgiven for thinking their efforts had been forgotten."Tragically, many who died were left in those foreign fields, in unmarked graves."On Victory in Japanday, those in the Far East were still overseas, or on board a ship in the middle of the ocean like Stan Smith from Barry, weeks or months from home."Those who ed were changed forever by their experiences."He added: "On Saturday, we will mark this important anniversary and pay tribute to all those affected by the war in the Far East and Pacic: Service personnel, their families and all civilians around the world."We pay our tributes to all of those affected by war, in our own extraordinary time, under the shadow of coronavirus, no doubt impacting our usual plans for commemorations."But at a time when we have had to make sacrices and suffered losses, we remember those  years ago who were there at the end of the most destructive conflict the world has ever seen."Those whose sacrice and suffering allowed the next generation to work towards peace."We thank you."We remember you."You will never be forgotten."Get involved:Take part in a two minute silence at am on Saturday, August Celebrate in your own homes ndash for ideas go to title: autumn date set opening new south lake leisure centre
story: Conleth Kane’s new debut album rockets to top ten in chartsPolice investigate financial irregularities at churchNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleCarsHomes and GardensNewsPeopleAutumn date set for opening of new South Lake Leisure CentreA date has been set for the opening of the new south lake leisure centre in Craigavon with the multi-million-pound facility to open its doors on November .By The NewsroomTuesday, th July , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th July , : pm""The largest capital project to date undertaken by ABC Council, and among the largest in Northern Ireland, the new multi-use sports and leisure complex is described by the council as a major new flagship health and wellbeing destination.Work on the facility was halted by the coronavirus outbreak. Since ing to site Farrans, the contractor in charge of the build, has ensured the contract is completed ready for opening in the Autumn.Farrans has been spearheading the build since initial enabling works got under way early in , creating  jobs on site during construction as part of a project which has delivered at least £. million in direct wages to the local economy.Located at the south side of Craigavon’s balancing lake, the facility is a landmark venue for the area and is situated within a pre-existing network of walking and cycling paths covering around three miles. The council hopes the new leisure centre will welcome visitors from across the borough and beyond to its new -metre pool, a young children’s indoor leisure water feature, a ,m state-of-the-art gym, multiple studios, health and wellbeing suite, sensory room, eight-court sports halls, spin studio, soft play area and an on-site café.It also incorporates an outdoor water sports provision offering a wide range of water based activities including windsurfing, water skiing and paddle sports. The council says the scale of South Lake Leisure Centre has been future-proofed to meet the needs of a growing population and a raising demand from a range of leisure, amateur and professional sporting enthusiasts.Lord Mayor of Armagh City, Banbridge and Craigavon, Councillor Kevin Savage, sai: “With a confirmed opening date just  weeks away, I am delighted that this stunning new centre - which will have fabulous facilities for everyone in the borough to access and enjoy - is almost complete.“South Lake Leisure Centre provides a once-in-a-generation opportunity to transform and dramatically enhance the quality of health and leisure provision within the borough, providing community access for everyone to the best facilities available in the UK and Ireland.”As part of the preparations for the official opening of South Lake Leisure Centre, interim arrangements have been agreed for leisure facilities in Portadownand Brownlow . Cascades Leisure Complex will be open to the public for lane swimming only in August, remaining open until Saturday th October.Craigavon Leisure Centre will remain open to the public for gym only until Monday th October. Waves Leisure Complex will be closed to the public.When all these facilities, which are approaching the end of their al le close, leisure staff will begin their training at the new South Lake Leisure Centre building.""Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"Most Popular." data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" data-s-el"" title"" class"sc-drMfKT fpqScQ"" alt"" layout"fill"" data-index"" data-s-event"gaEvent" data-s-ec"navigation" data-s-ea"most popular" title"" data-s-el"" class"sc-bGbJRg eOOfIS"This website and its associated newspaper are members of Independent Press Standards Organisation Follow us onExploreNewsSportWhats OnLestyleMore from Portadown TimesAnnouncementsJobsPublic NoticesMust ReadBuy a PhotoDirectoryLocal GuideReader ShopUseful LinksContact UsAdvertise My BusinessAdvertise a JobPlace your AdSubscribeEventsArchiveReaders Charter" fill"#ea"©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. ." target"_self" href"#" id"cookieSettings" class"sc-gxMtzJ sc-dfVpRl dLpuYr"Cookie SettingsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy policyNews you can trust since News" class"expand" role"button" tabindex""""" scale translate " points"  .  . When we were investing in developing the Wedding Suite we wanted to create a welcoming environment where brides could visit with their bridal party and enjoy the experience of choosing their wedding dress without any pressure.”Anne Crossan, Regional Retail Manager, SVP NI, said: “The new Vincent’s Wedding Suite is a wonderful addition to the service that we are providing to the local community in the Portadown area. I think it’s really important that brides feel comfortable and enjoy the experience of buying their wedding dress and being able to offer private appointments is a lovely way of personalising the experience for them and their families. I wish Michael and the staff well with this new offering for the store.”The Wedding Suite at Vincents PortadownBrides wishing to visit Vincent’s Wedding Suite can be accommodated by appointment during normal shop opening hours and also on evenings and at weekends. Council’s event to celebrate the th anniversary of VJ Day has been welcomed by both the DUP and Sinn Fein.By The NewsroomThursday, th August , : pm""Council has confirmed a shared history event to mark the occasion will take place this Saturday, August .Many local people were heldas Japanese prisoners of war and the stories of their experience still haunt the families to this day.The event will include a lecture from renowned historian Dr Eamon Phoenix, poetry reading by local historian Richard Edgar and a musical accompaniment from piper Ian Burrows.Speaking about the event, Council’s Lord Mayor, Councillor Kevin Savage said: “Shared history events are important for a ided society.“We hope that by embracing social media and digital technology we can attract wider audiences comprised of people who – for ious reasons – might not normally attend such an event in person.“With COVID- still very much a concern at the moment, we are hoping to run more online events like these to ensure we’re minimising the risk to our residents while still offering the excellent events we’re known for, albeit in a slightly dferent way.”DUP group whip Councillor Darryn Causby said it was important for Council to mark the occasion, widely regarded as the end of the second World War.“It is important for Council to mark this occasion,” he said.“We are obviously disappointed that it could not be marked in a more substantial way than what we are doing.“However, we welcome the fact all parties recognise the vital role the British Army played during the second World War and we welcome that across the piece.”Speaking about ABC Council’s shared history event SinnFein group leader, Councillor Liam Mackle said: “Many local people lost their lives in this conflict.“The Lord Mayor will pay special tribute to local man Jim Haughey. Jim fought against fascismin the International Brigade in the Spanish Civil War and was later killed in .“Council officers deserve special praise for organising this event which was inclusive and contributed to our shared understanding of history.”Initially proposed by DUP group leader, Councillor Mark Baxter duringthe course of July’s full council meeting, the idea to hold a socially distanced event compliant with COVID regulations was put to a vote following a fiery debate.In total,  members voted for the proposal with the DUP, UUP, Alliance Party and IndependentCouncillorPaul Berry in support of the proposal.The five SDLP members present abstained and the nine Sinn Fein members present voted against the proposal.The event will be broadcast on Council’s facebook page from -.am on Saturday, August .
